main_pages.title: Context
main_pages.description: On May 1, 1970 a group of 500 students led by history graduate students gathered here at the Victory Bell to protest President Nixonâ€™s announcement of the Cambodian Invasion the night before. After burying a copy of Constitution as a symbol of an expansion of an already unpopular war, the organizers called for a larger protest at noon on Monday, May 4, 1970.

main_pages.title: May 4, 1970
main_pages.description: After a weekend of turmoil off campus and on, an estimated 2000 people, gathered that Monday to protest the Vietnam War and the presence of the Ohio National Guard on campus

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: Since 1971, friends, family, and students gather in silence at the Victory Bell at 11:00 pm on May 3 for the start of the annual Candlelight Vigil and March. On May 4, the bell is rung 15 times-- once for each of the victims of the Kent State shooting and the two men killed at Jackson State.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: How is student activism different today?

content_items.item_description: A growing crowd gathers at the Victory Bell, May 4, 1970.
Trails of light from the first annual Candlelight March and Vigil, May 3, 1971.
